metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: React's goal is in many ways to render HTML in a web page.
content.html: React's goal is in many ways to render HTML in a web page.

content.text: React renders HTML to the web page by using a function called createRoot() and its method render() .
content.html: React renders HTML to the web page by using a function called createRoot() and its method render().

content.text: The createRoot() function takes one argument, an HTML element.
content.html: The createRoot() function takes one argument, an HTML element.

content.text: The purpose of the function is to define the HTML element where a React component should be displayed.
content.html: The purpose of the function is to define the HTML element where a React component should be displayed.

content.text: The render() method is then called to define the React component that should be rendered.
content.html: The render() method is then called to define the React component that should be rendered.

content.text: There is another folder in the root directory of your React project, named "public". In this folder, there is an index.html file.
content.html: There is another folder in the root directory of your React project, named "public". In this folder, there is an index.html file.

content.text: You'll notice a single <div> in the body of this file. This is where our React application will be rendered.
content.html: You'll notice a single <div> in the body of this file. This is where our React application will be rendered.

content.code:
const
container
=
document
.
getElementById
(
'root'
)
;


const
root
=
ReactDOM
.
createRoot
(
container
)
;

root
.
render
(
<
p
>
Hello
</
p
>
)
;
content.code_html:
const container = document.getElementById('root');
const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(container);
root.render(<p>Hello</p>);

content.text: Note that the element id does not have to be called "root", but this is the standard convention.
content.html: Note that the element id does not have to be called "root", but this is the standard convention.

content.text: The HTML code in this tutorial uses JSX which allows you to write HTML tags inside the JavaScript code:
content.html: The HTML code in this tutorial uses JSX which allows you to write HTML tags inside the JavaScript code:

content.text: Do not worry if the syntax is unfamiliar, you will learn more about JSX in the next chapter.
content.html: Do not worry if the syntax is unfamiliar, you will learn more about JSX in the next chapter.

content.code_html:
const myelement = (
  <table>
    <tr>
      <th>Name</th>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td>John</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td>Elsa</td>
    </tr>
  </table>
);

const container = document.getElementById('root');
const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(container);
root.render(myelement);

content.text: The root node is the HTML element where you want to display the result.
content.html: The root node is the HTML element where you want to display the result.

content.text: It is like a container for content managed by React.
content.html: It is like a container for content managed by React.

content.text: It does NOT have to be a <div> element and it does NOT have to have the id='root' :
content.html: It does NOT have to be a <div> element and it does NOT have to have the id='root':

  <header id="sandy"></header>

</body>
